text: A day in LATE AUGUST. A FIGURE on a hill top; the unpopul landscape - lush in summer, barren and bleak in winter - curving down to high chalk cliffs with the ocean beyond. GABRIEL OAK sits watching over his flock with his two DOG his face handsome if somewhat weather-beaten beneath a lo crowned felt hat. He has a quality of contentment, calm a stillness. Idly, he plays with a stone in his hand. No so but the sounds of nature. Which is why his eye is drawn towards the horizon, the so of wheels. A CART is approaching. Curious GABRIEL rises a walks closer, as the CART stops at a toll gate and the OL WAGGONER gets down.
From GABRIEL’s p.o.v, an argument has broken out with the TURNPIKE KEEPER.
Misses says she won’t pay more.
Then Misses’d best turn back. Price is thrupence. The WAGGONER sighs, and goes to negotiate with his PASSEN as yet unseen. GABRIEL steps closer.
Perhaps best to pay him. Be dark soon. She replies - barely heard. The WAGGONER returns.
She says she’s paid you quite enough.
Three pence. A stand-off. Until GABRIEL arrives. He knows the GATEKEEP A local.

Let her through. It’s a woman on her own.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 2 Going through the gate, BATHSHEBA EVERDENE very briefly t to GABRIEL. If she feels gratitude, she can’t quite bring herself to express it. Pride wins out. The cart moves on.

TITLES - ‘FAR FROM THE MADDING CROWD.’ 3 Under TITLES, a series of Wessex landscapes. - CARROW COVE on a brisk autumn day, the low sun glinting the sea. - the CLIFFS of NORCOMBE HILL facing out into the sea in grip of a winter storm. - the RIVER AXE in full flow with the melting snows of spring. - bleak EGDON HEATH in the rain, the road seeming to stre on forever. - the gloom of the GREAT FOREST, dark in its depths even the brightest summer day. - the mud and stone of ploughed fields in the VALE of BLACKMORE, awaiting planting in March. This is the stage for our story, quite remote from the re of the world. A grand landscape, sometimes beautiful, sometimes harsh - - and finally, the slope of NORCOMBE HILL on a day in LAT SEPTEMBER.

location: STABLE, MRS HURST FARM, NORCOMBE HILL

text: LATE SEPTEMBER. A chink of light opens out as the stable is pulled open. BATHSHEBA is silhouetted against the brig light.

BATHSHEBA leads the horse into the yard of MRS HURST’s fa small, subsistence-level but tidy and well-kept, clinging the side of the remote hill. We see her face as she greets the horse; a startlingly vi face, full of spirit and determination. She rides off.
FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 3
- heading down to the forest that borders the hill.

BATHSHEBA finds herself in a hollow-way, a path covered b canopy of trees, too low for rider and horse to pass bene She looks one way, then the other, to ensure that she’s a then, in a single dextrous movement, then switches from s saddle to cross-saddle, tucking her dress up - some sort trousers or breaches revealed beneath. Comfortable now, s lies backwards along the horse so that her head is near i tail, her feet near its shoulders, her eyes to the sky. I an impressive performance, almost a circus trick, and she smiles in satisfaction to herself as the horse trots forw the sky showing between the low boughs. On the ground behind her, a SCARF.
- towards a high vantage point. The panorama is magnifice and she smiles to herself. She urges the horse on, a wonderful rider, riding past GABRIEL without even stopping.

The SCARF again, but now it lies on the table of GABRIEL OAK’s cottage, a neat, comfortable place. GABRIEL sits nearby, counting out money which he locks aw in a strong box. He closes his money box. His eye returns to the SCARF - EXT. GABRIEL’S COTTAGE - DAY 8 Another day. From his high vantage point, GABRIEL with hi sheep and dogs, behind him his cottage. He sees BATHSHEBA walking by, below.
Miss! In his hand, the lost SCARF. He stays proudly on top of t hill, so she has to climb the hill towards him. He hands the scarf.
FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 4
(out of breath) My scarf. I lost it. You must be Farmer Oak. (surprise from GABRIEL) This is your land, I must be trespassing.
You're welcome here. Gabriel. And you are...?
I’d rather not tell you. It’s a very odd name, I try not to say it out loud.
I’m sure you could get a new one. If you wanted. (An awkward moment, a misfire. She takes the scarf -) Forgive me, I can’t always..map my mind on my tongue.

Thank you. Farmer Oak. On BATHSHEBA as she walks away, a small smile appearing. EXT. MRS HURST’S FARM, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 8A BATHSHEBA is milking the cows. GABRIEL is herding his she nearby, heading up to the small SHEPHERD’S HUT, a kind of CARAVAN from where he guards the sheep. A greeting between them. She steps out and looks after hi The ice melting - EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 8B GABRIEL has two dogs, YOUNG GEORGE who barks and nips at flock, and OLD GEORGE who sits contentedly by BATHSHEBA. A new development. BATHSHEBA watches GABRIEL go about his work with some admiration. GABRIEL, for his part, is show off a little.
Come by, George. Come! (Returning to BATHSHEBA) He’s keen enough, Young George, but he doesn’t know when to stop. (petting OLD GEORGE) (MORE )
10 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 5
Not like this one. Been with me a long time, haven’t you?
And what’s that one called?
This is Old George.
(she laughs) Of course. Old George. And GABRIEL walks away towards his caravan.
Find me amusing, do you?

BATHSHEBA is out riding once more. She stops. It’s a beautiful night, the stars framing her, steam rising from horse. From somewhere in the distance, the sound of dogs barking. Some distance away stands GABRIEL’s hut, the small buildi on wheels that he uses for shelter when watching the floc night. Smoke rises from the chimney. But something is amiss. We follow her towards the caravan. She knocks on the door no answer. She goes in and finds - INT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - NIGHT 10 GABRIEL lies unconscious in the smoky interior. BATHSHEBA takes in the scene then leaps into action. With all her strength, she drags him upright, slaps his face.

Mr Oak! Mr Oak, wake up! Gabriel Oak! Nothing. Now she tries to haul him to her feet. But he fa a dead-weight, across her lap. This is all new to BATHSHE A man in her lap. She takes it in. To her side, a jug of milk. She takes it, throws it into his face. Gasping, dazed and confused he comes round. Looks up, see her face. She laughs with relief. GABRIEL is confused, breathless.
What’s the matter? What is it?  11 12 13 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 6

Nothing, since you’re not dead. I was heading home when I heard the dogs barking. (she busies herself, ventilating the hut) It's very foolish of you, Farmer. Oak. My uncle had a hut just like this, I used to play in it asa little girl and he told me, always, always keep a window open or you'll suffocate. ( - the wetness - ) I’m sorry about the milk. At least it was warm. (he attempts to stand, stumbles. Takes her HAND) Rest a moment. You know, Farmer Oak, I think I may have saved your life. Her hand in his, as GABRIEL steadies himself.
Tell me your name. I still don’t know your name.

Then find it out. My hand, Mr Oak? Somewhat reluctantly, he lets go of her hand. She walks o into the night. GABRIEL sits on the steps and watches her go. EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 11 Next morning. GABRIEL is working his sheep, but his mind elsewhere. He stops working, his mind wandering. INT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 12 GABRIEL polishes his boots, puts away his working clothes decision has been made. EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 13 GABRIEL walks through his flock and finds a lamb. It has weeks early, and is the only one. He scoops the tiny thin up.  14 15 16 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 7 EXT. MRS HURST’S COTTAGE -— DAY 14 Accompanied by OLD GEORGE, carrying the lamb, GABRIEL mar towards MRS HURST’s, a man with a mission. Middle-aged, wry and weather-worn, MRS HURST joins her ni in clearing brambles from the cottage garden. Tough work, BATHSHEBA scratched and muddy. MRS HURST stretches out her back and notices GABRIEL approaching.
Goodness. Mr Oak.

What does he want? INT. KITCHEN, MRS HURST’S COTTAGE - DAY 15 BATHSHEBA washes the mud from her hands, wipes it from he face, checks her reflection in the small mirror. It will to do. INT. PARLOUR, MRS HURST’S COTTAGE -— CONTINUOUS 16 GABRIEL and MRS HURST sit in the parlour, a little awkwar BATHSHEBA enters, and he stands abruptly.
Miss Everdene. Bathsheba. I’ve brought you a lamb.
(delighted) Thank you, Farmer Oak! Such a dear thing, that’s very sweet of you.
He’s come too soon and won’t last the winter. I thought you’d like to rear it instead.
Thank you. That’s very kind. MRS HURST takes the lamb out with her.
I’1ll make some tea. And she makes her exit. Silence.
The lamb is not why I came.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 8
Go on.
Well...I wanted to ask, Miss Everdene, if you’d marry me. A long moment.
Oh - This is not the response he wanted -
I’ve never asked anyone before.
No, I - And impulsively he stands.
Well. I’1l leave you now.
Mr Oak - (he turns, waits) There are things to consider.
Someone waiting for you?
No, there’s no-one else but that doesn’t mean I’1l marry you.
Good day to you then. 17 EXT. MRS HURST’S COTTAGE - CONTINUOUS 17 BATHSHEBA follows him out.
Mr Oak, stop! I didn’t say I wouldn’t marry you either! (he doesn’t understand - which is it?) I really haven’t ever thought about it. I need time to consider.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 9

But I know I can make you happy. (she’s thrown by this) I have one hundred acres, two hundred sheep, When I pay off the money, the farm is ours. You could have a piano in a year or two. Flowers and birds. A frame for cucumbers. A baby perhaps, or two -
Please, Mr Oak, that’s too much -
- or more. And whenever you look up I’1l be there, and whenever I look up there’ll be you. BATHSHEBA takes this in, imagines it, and makes her decis
Mr Oak, I do not want a husband. I'd hate to be some man’s property. I shouldn't mind being a bride at a wedding, if I could be one without getting a husband, but -
That’s just stupid talk. With as much calmness and compassion as she can muster;
You are better off than I, Mr Oak. I have an education and this dress and nothing more. You can do much, much better than me...
Maybe that’s true. But you know that’s not the reason.
I’m too independent for you. (this sounds more plausible) If I ever were to marry, I’d need somebody to tame me, and you’d never be able to do it. You'd grow to despise me.
(with quiet simplicity) I would not. (she takes this in. A moment, then -) Goodbye, Miss Everdene.  18 19 20

FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 10 And with that he turns and goes. For a moment she follows him, just a step or two. Then sh walks back to the cottage. One last look. GABRIEL walks away, no turning back. EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 18 WINTER. Time passing. GABRIEL is herding sheep as light snow falls. Hard, physi work. As night comes on, he rests on the steps of the Shepherd' Hut, the site of BATHSHEBA’s rescue.

Another day. In his caravan, OLD GEORGE by his side, GABR sleeps on. The barking of YOUNG GEORGE wakes them both. Something is He sits, listens. The sound of sheep bells now. He is on his feet. To OLD GEORGE -—
Stay here, old boy.

GABRIEL steps out of the caravan, pulling on his clothes. listens to the distant barking to find the direction, the runs off. A broken fence nearby - EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAWN 20A He walks through trees, losing track of the barking for a moment. Coming out of the trees and forest, he crests the hill in search of the flock. But they have gone. Disappeared. Silence. Then barking, the sound of the bells, further off this ti He runs —  21 22 23 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 11

A natural basin leads up to cliffs and, beyond that, the The precipice is fenced off, but it is towards this cliff edge that the flock have been harried by YOUNG GEORGE. GABRIEL stumbles across the darkened hillside after them. ---but it’s too late. The young, impetuous dog is barking snapping at a single remaining sheep, forcing it through gap in the broken fence and into the darkness beyond. The sheep has gone. YOUNG GEORGE runs to his master, desperate for approval. GABRIEL is numb. With a terrible sense of foreboding, he walks towards the gap in the hedge, knowing already what he'll find. GABRIEL’s POV. A glimpse of white below.

At the bottom of the limestone cliff, the corpses of the flock. Two hundred sheep, all dead. The sun is up, the water lapping at the corpses. GABRIEL stands exhausted, numb. All of his hopes, his ambitions, rewards of twenty years hard work, all dead. At his side, YOUNG GEORGE licks his hand, awaiting his reward for a jo well done. He kneels next to YOUNG GEORGE, places his forehead again the dog’s and speaks to him quietly.

Least we didn’t marry, eh Georgie? Then he quickly stands and, without malice but with an aw resignation, he raises his gun. A shot rings out. INT. GABRIEL’S COTTAGE - DAY 23 Keys and cashbox handed to two GENTLEMAN FARMERS.
Good luck to you, Mr Oak.
And our sympathies.
Where are you heading? (no reply) We take no pleasure in this.  24 25 26 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 12 GABRIEL ignores them and goes instead to OLD GEORGE.
Sorry, old boy.
Another day. GABRIEL walks on, everything he owns now in pack on his back. Now snow falls. The road across Egdon Heath has disappear Desperate for shelter, he sees a barn.
GABRIEL wraps himself in his blanket and tries to sleep, breath hanging in the frozen air. There’s a hole in the roof. GABRIEL looks to the skies, thinks of BATHSHEBA - EXT. MRS HURST’S FARM - DAY 26
Bathsheba! A shout. BATHSHEBA, working in the fields, stands. MRS HU runs towards her, waving something in her hand.
What is it? A letter. She hands it to BATHSHEBA, breathless. Gasping air -
Oh my love, it’s your poor Uncle's will.
What does it say? What’s happened? Breathless, MRS HURST indicates.

Read it! Read! BATHSHEBA does so - BATHSHEBA puts her hand to her mouth. Then she embraces h AUNT.  27 28 29 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 13 EXT. MRS HURST’S COTTAGE - DAY 27 The cart is loaded with suitcases and furniture. In her c dress once more, BATHSHEBA says farewell - - then clambers aboard, and finds a place amongst the precarious load. The cart trundles off, BATHSHEBA turning and waving goodb Excitement, anticipation. On her lap, the lamb. GABRIEL’s gift. The blare of a trumpet and -

CLOSE on SERGEANT FRANCIS TROY of the 11th DRAGOON GUARDS Fine-boned, a neatly-trimmed moustache on a finely struct face. The DRAGOONS are a splendid sight, a blaze of brass and scarlet on a January day. They ride towards the market town of CASTERBRIDGE EXT. TOWN SQUARE, CASTERBRIDGE -— DAY 29 The GUARDS are holding an opportunistic recruiting drive. TROY and the other troops stand at ease SERGEANT DOGGETT, attempts to muster new recruits.

So who'll join us, lads? Which of you fine boys’1l put on the scarlet uniform and proudly serve his Queen and Country?... In amongst the crowd, a YOUNG WOMAN. She’s in her best dr but painfully under-dressed for the cold weather. She’s a encumbered by a large, impractical carpet bag. Neverthele there’s a kind of elation about her, as if she’s embarkin some adventure. An escape. This is FANNY ROBBIN. She pushes through the crowd towards the front, finding herself next to GABRIEL OAK; gaunt now, exhausted.
Frank! Over here! Frank, it’s Fanny! TROY gives her a quick, fond glance, then fixes his eyes forward again.
(to GABRIEL) My sweetheart. Over there.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 14

You, sir... (he has spotted GABRIEL) .---next to the pretty lady! (FANNY ROBBIN blushes) There’s a good strong figure of a man. Always room in the ranks for gentlemen of your calibre. Come join us, sir! A moment of hesitation.
Go on. You’d make a fine soldier. But GABRIEL shakes his head and shrinks back into the cro walking away as DOGGETT continues.
Or that gentleman there, you look like a patriot. Come on lad, don’t be shy, step forward... GABRIEL takes one more look over his shoulder, then heads his way. But FANNY has followed him -
You might try Weatherbury! (GABRIEL turns) If you're looking for work, try Weatherbury. There’s a farm there needs all the help it can get.
Thank you. I’1l do that. (a moment. He notices her carpet-bag, her thin clothes) You should have a cloak, cold night like this.
(with forced pride) Oh, no, Francis’ll take care of me. He’s a sergeant. We’re going to be married soon you see.
But tonight, you have lodgings?
No. Not tonight. Not yet. GABRIEL reaches into his pocket and offers her a coin.  30 31 32 33 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 15

I am taken care of. (Pride vs. Necessity. GABRIEL persists.) But if you’re sure can spare it... (and she takes it) I‘ll repay you. I'll send it to Weatherbury. But please, don’t tell anyone there you saw me. I’ve run away you see. Let it be our secret. GABRIEL nods assent and she hurries off, carrying all her possessions.
GABRIEL walks on towards Weatherbury now. Exhausted, it’s time to rest.

A feeble camp fire. Scooping leaves into a pile, GABRIEL makes a mattress of sorts in the woods. Exhausted from th day's humiliations, he pulls his blanket up and tries to sleep. The NOISES of the wood at night. And then a new noise. SH of alarm. GABRIEL sits. Through the trees, a red glow like the end cigar...

Half a mile away a fire is clearly visible, blazing out o control. Human shouts, the panic of cattle and horses. From the edge of the woods, GABRIEL watches impassively. of his business. Nothing to do with him. Then a decision. He heads off towards the flames.

A hayrick in flames, burning with startling speed and intensity. The farmyard is in chaos; livestock crying in panic as me run uselessly back and forth in the orange light. At pres it’s the only one on fire, but a number of ricks stand cl and burning straw tumbles through the air, across to the great BARN that holds the crop.  34 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 16 A rag-tag group of farmhands - JOSEPH, JACOB, BILLY, LABA CAINY and JAN - all hurl water uselessly onto the flames. GABRIEL arrives.
Who’s in charge here?
Who are you?
Who’s in charge? Where’s your farmer?
Look - the barn! Sure enough, the fire has spread to the roof of the barn, where all the crop is kept.
This rick is lost. It’s the barn you need to save. D’you understand? They stare uselessly at the stranger.
Ladder?

It was on the rick. GABRIEL thinks for a moment. He takes the scarf from JOSE neck and wraps it around his face, making a make-shift ma Then he grabs a bucket of water, pours it over his head, strides towards the barn.
A haywain has ignited, burning furiously down one side, t side nearest the barn.

Get it away! Now! And he leads the men in pulling the flaming cart away fro the precious barn. But it’s too late! The barn roof is starting to burn. They do so, but the cart itself is in flames now. GABRIEL steadies himself and looks across to the barn roof.  35 36 37 38 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 17
GABRIEL runs inside, through smoke and the crop, searchin for a way to the roof. The whole building is a tinderbox, he clambers to the highest level despite the flames above him.
And now he appears on the roof (through a hatch? via a ladder? TO BE DISCUSSED) and begins smothering the burnin thatch as the MEN watch from below.

The fire is extinguished. Thick smoke hangs in the air, a battlefield after the fighting. GABRIEL, blackened and exhausted, is washing the soot from his face. He gathers possessions, ready to move on, when a maid approaches. Th is LIDDY -
The farmer’s here.
About time too. Where’s he been?
She'd like to thank you. GABRIEL stops still. Stands straight. A FIGURE approaches, her face covered against the smoke. WOMAN. She slows. Stops. She uncovers her face -
No. It can’t be. GABRIEL smiles. And BATHSHEBA EVERDENE, owner of Weatherb Farm smiles back at him.
Mr Oak, is that really you?
Do you happen to want a shepherd, ma’ am?
As a matter of fact, I do.
As the WORKERS clear away the fire damage, BATHSHEBA and walk.
FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 18
I owe you an immense debt, Mr Oak. If I’d lost the barn, I’d have lost my farm.
Your farm?

It's my inheritance - And they turn a corner, REVEALING the main house, a littl run-down perhaps, but still fine and imposing. BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) I loved it here as a little girl. When my uncle passed away, he left it to me. Of course it’s a little ragged now but this was once the finest farm for miles. I intend to make it so again. (she glances at Gabriel) Perhaps you find the idea preposterous too, Mr Oak?
I no longer have that luxury.

I’m truly sorry to hear of your great loss, Mr Oak, but if this reversal of fortunes causes you any embarrassment... (GABRIEL is silent) ) I think it best if you address me as ‘ma’am’ or ‘Miss Everdene’. In turn I will address you as Mr Oak.
I understand. Ma’am. An awkward smile, and she goes.

BATHSHEBA sits at a great oak table, a cash box in front her. A noise from the doorway - LIDDY, BATHSHEBA’s maid, frien and confidante.  39 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 19 Fiercely protective of her mistress and, despite being th daughter of BILLY SMALLBURY, fiercely proud of her status
Miss, the philistines are upon us! The MEN loiter in the doorway, waiting to be paid.
Send them in.

A little later. Paid or waiting to be paid are - JAN COGGAN - strong, capable, reliable, a companionable bachelor. LABAN TALL. Handsome, conceited, suspicious of GABRIEL’s charm. JOSEPH POORGRASS is weak, physically inept, painfully shy especially around BATHSHEBA. JACOB SMALLBURY, LIDDY’s grandfather, is the self-appoint elder statesman, given to wise pronouncements, alcohol an laziness. BILLY SMALLBURY, his son, is reliable, slightly put-upon both father and daughter. CAINY BALL is an awkward teenager, easily distracted, alw in the way. TEDDY COGGAN, JAN’s young brother, is the youngest, indul and spoiled by the others. TEMPERANCE and SOBERNESS MILLER are the opposite of what their names suggest; flirtatious, irreverent, ‘yielding’. MRS COGGAN is the housekeeper and cook, JAN’s mother, perpetually harassed and dusted in flour. SUSAN TALL is the ferocious, controlling wife of Laban, perpetually enraged at his boozing, his lack of social advancement. MARYANN MONEY is LIDDY’s side-kick, good-humoured, a drea easily perplexed.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 20 BATHSHEBA hands out the money to each in turn, LIDDY prou by her side. Next up is -
Joseph Poorgrass! Which one is Joseph Poorgrass? JOSPEH POORGRASS steps forward. LIDDY indicates ‘hat off’ BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) And what do you do, Joseph Poorgrass?
I does general things and in Spring I shoot the rooks and help at pig- killing, Sir, I mean Ma’am.
Here’s seven and ninepence, and another ten shillings as I’m new.
Thank you, Ma’am.
Now. Fanny Robbin? Where is she?
She has run away ma’am. With a soldier. GABRIEL picks up on this -
Not a soldier, a sergeant! Sceptical laughter. BATHSHEBA is unamused.
Bailiff Pennyways, here is ten shillings and a further ten. This ends our association. You are dismissed.
Beg pardon, ma’am?
When my uncle was alive, this was a fine, productive farm. Since his death it has fallen into ruin - PENNYWAYS leans into BATHSHEBA, his face full of menace. GABRIEL stands, at the ready.
Now see here, Miss -  40 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 21

- a fire threatens to destroy the barn and you’re nowhere to be found. I have no use for men like you, Mr Pennyways. You are dismissed. She holds her nerve. PENNYWAYS’s bluff is called. A momen he scans the room for support that will not come. Address the others -
I'd get out while you can if I was you! And he leaves. If BATHSHEBA is shaken, she hides it well. Settling herself.
Now. You’ve met Mr Oak, our new shepherd. You understand your duties, Mr Oak?
If I don’t, I'll ask you. Ma’am.

(she stands to address the room) From now on you have a mistress, not a master. I don’t yet know my talents in farming, but I shall do my best. If you suppose, because I’m a woman, that I don’t know bad from good, right from wrong, then leave. But to those who choose to stay, I promise you this. I shall be up before you are awake, I shall be in the fields before you are up. It is my intention to astonish you all. Now - back to work, please. She stands and leaves the room. The WORKERS look on, some impressed, some sceptical, some duly astonished.

As the evening falls, FANNY walks through the mud of a riverside path in barely adequate shoes towards MELCHESTE BARRACKS. She still carries her carpet-bag, still on the move. It’s a barren, bleak landscape, and some of the hope, som the certainty has gone from FANNY’s adventure.  41 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 22 EXT. MELCHESTER BARRACKS — DUSK 41 A river. A wall, high and blank, with shuttered windows. FANNY counts the windows -
One, two, three, four... She picks up a handful of earth, throws it. The small win opens, and TROY appears.
Who’s there?
Is it Sergeant Frank Troy?
Who is it?
Frank, don’t you know me? Fanny Robbin!
Fanny!
Yes!
How did you get here?
You said I was to come.
Well...I said that you might. You’re too late!
You can’t come out and see me?
No no, the barrack gates are closed and I have no leave. I'll find you tomorrow.
Tomorrow! Oh, Frank. Then I won’t see you till then?
Do you have a place to stay?
Yes. No. I’1l find somewhere. When will it be?  42 43 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 23
What?
What you promised...Don’t make me say it. You say it first!
You say it.
When will we get married?
Soon —
Have you asked permission?
If I said I’1l marry you, I will.
Oh, I love you Francis Troy!
Shhhh! Tomorrow. He closes the window but FANNY lingers, full of hope.

Market Day. The building is at the very heart of the town imposing, high-domed and noisy, a sort of stock-exchange grain. Outside, BATHSHEBA and LIDDY hoist hefty bags of grain samples from her carriage and heads towards the entrance.
Inside, it’s a temple of commerce, and a strictly male preserve that echoes with bargaining, banter and deal-mak - until BATHSHEBA enters, LIDDY behind her.

(a whisper) We have a perfect right to be here. All heads turn. They could not be more surprised if a sma elephant had entered the hall. A silence. Then the murmur gossip, disapproval, some admiration. Meanwhile, one WELL-DRESSED GENTLEMAN clears his throat.  44 45 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 24

Gentlemen, shall we return to business? This man is BOLDWOOD, forties, self-contained, handsome i Roman way; dignified, the nearest Casterbridge has to aristocracy, and clearly a step above the tradesmen aroun him. Needless to say, BATHSHEBA notices him -— But indifferent, BOLDWOOD returns to business.
A little later. Still BATHSHEBA stands alone, looking for first customer as the MALE CROWD mills around her. LIDDY returns;
Perhaps we should go, Miss. But a FARMER catches her eye. There’s nothing for it -
It’s Farmer Stone, isn’t it? I’m Farmer Everdene’s niece. He talked about you with such admiration. A moment. And the FARMER approaches -—
And now BATHSHEBA is surrounded by FARMERS. She is enjoyi herself now, as she pours the grain sample into FARMER STONE’s hand.
How much?
Five pounds a quarter.
Three pounds ten shillings.
